}} 'Leptin' (Greek Î»ÎµÏÏÏÏ (leptos) meaning "thin") is a 16-kDa protein hormone
that plays a key role in regulating energy intake and expenditure, including
appetite and hunger, metabolism, and behavior. It is one of the most important
adipose-derived hormones. Leptin functions by
binding to the leptin receptor. The Ob(Lep) gene (Ob for obese, Lep for leptin)
is located on chromosome 7 in humans.
